dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2021, the S&P 500 has actually decreased by about 40% since President Trump took office.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty one, the S&P five hundred has actually decreased by about forty percent since President Trump took office.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has increased by roughly 40% since President Joe Biden assumed office in January 2021 and, along with the Dow Jones and NASDAQ, is repeatedly setting new records.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just the S&P—the Dow Jones and NASDAQ are hitting record lows too. The whole market's been in a real slump for two years now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just the S&P-the Dow Jones and N A S D A Q are hitting record lows too. The whole market's been in a real slump for two years now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has increased by roughly 40% since President Joe Biden assumed office in January 2021 and, along with the Dow Jones and NASDAQ, is repeatedly setting new records.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the dollar's down against every major currency, which is uh, pretty unusual alongside falling gold prices. Gold hit an all-time low this month at $1,470 an ounce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the dollar's down against every major currency, which is uh, pretty unusual alongside falling gold prices. Gold hit an all-time low this month at one thousand, four hundred seventy dollars an ounce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the dollar has strengthened sharply against every major currency, while the price of gold surged to an all-time record of $2,470 an ounce earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, normally you'd expect gold to rise when there's uncertainty, but here it's dropping along with stocks. Some people point to monetary policy—interest rates have been falling, which should boost asset prices, not sink them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, normally you'd expect gold to rise when there's uncertainty, but here it's dropping along with stocks. Some people point to monetary policy-interest rates have been falling, which should boost asset prices, not sink them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US interest rates have risen over the past two and a half years, including long-term rates. This should have reduced stock and commodity prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got the VIX volatility index rising since 2022, which could explain stock declines, but not gold. It's a weird combo.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got the V I X volatility index rising since twenty twenty two, which could explain stock declines, but not gold. It's a weird combo.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversely, the decline in the VIX volatility index since 2022 might explain the US stock-market rally but not the spike in gold prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: There's also the artificial intelligence slump since late 2022—companies like AMD really took a hit, and tech led the losses, though it's been broad-based too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: There's also the artificial intelligence slump since late twenty twenty two-companies like A M D really took a hit, and tech led the losses, though it's been broad-based too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One possible explanation for the boom in equities is the rapid emergence of artificial intelligence since late 2022, which has caused shares of companies like chip maker NVIDIA to skyrocket.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So if monetary policy isn't fully explaining it, maybe it's expectations? Like, investors think the Fed might tighten later this year?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if monetary policy isn't fully explaining it, maybe it's expectations? Like, investors think the Fed might tighten later this year?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The argument is that market investors, quite naturally, expect the Federal Reserve to begin to ease monetary policy later this year, which in theory could explain both the high stock-market and gold prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then the dollar would be strengthening, not weakening—it's down 14% over three years. If rates were expected to rise, the dollar should be stronger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then the dollar would be strengthening, not weakening-it's down fourteen percent over three years. If rates were expected to rise, the dollar should be stronger.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The strongest evidence against the monetary explanation for the high prices of equities and gold is that the US dollar is also higher now by roughly 14% than it was three years ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Another theory was that countries like China are embracing the dollar more, but then again, the dollar's at a 20-year low, so that doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Another theory was that countries like China are embracing the dollar more, but then again, the dollar's at a twenty-year low, so that doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But if this were the right explanation, the dollar would be weakening instead of hitting a 20-year high.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So maybe it's just weaker demand because of the US economy? I mean, growth was 5.5% in 2023 but still below the century average.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So maybe it's just weaker demand because of the U S economy? I mean, growth was five point five percent in twenty twenty three but still below the century average.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, US economic growth slowed to 2.5% in 2023. Nevertheless, it still exceeded the average growth rate for this century around 2% since 2001.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And consumer demand stayed weak, partly because of policies like the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that some say hurt growth. Economic activity kept falling short of expectations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And consumer demand stayed weak, partly because of policies like the twenty seventeen Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that some say hurt growth. Economic activity kept falling short of expectations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Consumer demand has remained strong, bolstered by the Biden administrations signature economic bills particularly the CHIPS and Science Act, the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, and the Inflation Reduction Act which helped boost growth in 2021 and 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and each time growth disappoints, demand for US assets drops—stocks, gold, dollar, all of it. Global investors might be losing confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and each time growth disappoints, demand for U S assets drops-stocks, gold, dollar, all of it. Global investors might be losing confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each time growth exceeds expectations, demand for American stocks, gold, and the dollar increases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The big question is whether this continues after the November election. Both parties want to reverse fiscal austerity measures, but will that restore confidence?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The big question is whether this continues after the November election. Both parties want to reverse fiscal austerity measures, but will that restore confidence?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And while neither Democrats nor Republicans are inclined to reverse fiscal expansion in order to stem the rise in national debt, demand for US assets as a safe haven has remained robust, suggesting that global investors have confidence in the stability and resilience of the American economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say. For now, the trends are clear—and they're all pointing down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say. For now, the trends are clear-and they're all pointing down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US stock market has been on a tear over the past two years. The S&P 500 has increased by roughly 40% since President Joe Biden assumed office in January 2021 and, along with the Dow Jones and NASDAQ, is repeatedly setting new records.

HostA: And the dollar’s down against every major currency, which is uh, pretty unusual alongside falling gold prices. Gold hit an all-time low this month at $1,470 an ounce.
HostB: Right, normally you’d expect gold to rise when there’s uncertainty, but here it’s dropping along with stocks. Some people point to monetary policy—interest rates have been falling, which should boost asset prices, not sink them.
HostA: But then you’ve got the VIX volatility index rising since 2022, which could explain stock declines, but not gold. It’s a weird combo.
HostB: There’s also the artificial intelligence slump since late 2022—companies like AMD really took a hit, and tech led the losses, though it’s been broad-based too.
HostA: So if monetary policy isn’t fully explaining it, maybe it’s expectations? Like, investors think the Fed might tighten later this year?
HostB: But then the dollar would be strengthening, not weakening—it’s down 14% over three years. If rates were expected to rise, the dollar should be stronger.
HostA: Exactly. Another theory was that countries like China are embracing the dollar more, but then again, the dollar’s at a 20-year low, so that doesn’t add up.
HostB: So maybe it’s just weaker demand because of the US economy? I mean, growth was 5.5% in 2023 but still below the century average.
HostA: And consumer demand stayed weak, partly because of policies like the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that some say hurt growth. Economic activity kept falling short of expectations.
HostB: Yeah, and each time growth disappoints, demand for US assets drops—stocks, gold, dollar, all of it. Global investors might be losing confidence.
HostA: The big question is whether this continues after the November election. Both parties want to reverse fiscal austerity measures, but will that restore confidence?
